title: 115_hr1973
content: The Act titled "Protecting Young Victims from Sexual Abuse Act of 2017" requires reporting of child and sexual abuse at facilities under amateur sports organizations recognized by the United States Olympic Committee. The Victims of Child Abuse Act of 1990 is amended to include reporting requirements for covered professionals and individuals who suspect child abuse. They must report to the designated agency promptly. The term 'covered individual' is defined as an adult authorized to interact with minors at sports facilities or events. The term 'event' includes travel, practice, competition, and medical treatment. The terms 'amateur athlete', 'amateur sports organization', and 'national governing body' are defined as per section 220501(b) of title 36, United States Code. The text amends various subsections of a section in title 36, United States Code, related to reporting child abuse at sports facilities. It clarifies that victims of child abuse are not required to self-report. Additionally, a penalty for failure to report is added to title 18, United States Code. The text amends a section in title 36, United States Code, regarding reporting child abuse at sports facilities. It clarifies that victims of child abuse are not required to self-report and adds a penalty for failure to report in title 18, United States Code. Additionally, it includes provisions for covered individuals as described in subsection (a)(2) of the section. The text introduces a civil remedy for personal injuries. Section 2255 of title 18, United States Code is amended to allow minors who were victims of specific violations to sue for damages in District Court, including actual or liquidated damages of $150,000, attorney's fees, and punitive damages. Section 2255 of title 18, United States Code is amended to allow minors who were victims of specific violations to sue for damages in District Court. The amendment includes a provision for filing within 10 years of discovering the violation or injury, or within 10 years of a legal disability ending. Venue and service of process details are also specified for such actions. In actions under subsection (a) of Section 2255 of title 18, process can be served in any district where the defendant is an inhabitant or can be found. SEC. 4. EXPANSION OF AUTHORITIES AND DUTIES OF AMATEUR SPORTS ORGANIZATIONS RECOGNIZED BY THE UNITED STATES OLYMPIC COMMITTEE TO PREVENT THE ABUSE OF MINOR AND AMATEUR ATHLETES. Expansion of authorities and duties of amateur sports organizations recognized by the United States Olympic Committee to prevent abuse of minor and amateur athletes, including physical and sexual abuse. Develop training, oversight practices, policies, and procedures to prevent such abuse. The curr_chunk discusses the development and enforcement of policies to prevent abuse of minor or amateur athletes, including physical and sexual abuse, by requiring adults interacting with athletes to report any suspected abuse to authorities. The curr_chunk outlines measures to prevent child abuse in amateur sports organizations, including reporting mechanisms for incidents, avoiding one-on-one interactions between minors and adults, and involving trained experts in resolving allegations. The curr_chunk details oversight procedures, audits, and resources required to prevent sexual abuse in sports organizations. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of listing resources on the national governing body's website and establishing mechanisms to report suspected sexual misconduct in sports organizations. The curr_chunk discusses the requirement for amateur sports organizations under a national governing body to confidentially share reports of sexual misconduct and review them to assess allegations. The curr_chunk discusses withholding interaction between adults accused of sexual misconduct and minors or athletes until allegations are resolved. It also outlines limited liability for the United States Olympic Committee and national governing bodies regarding sexual misconduct allegations. The curr_chunk addresses the scope of liability for entities investigating sexual misconduct allegations in sports, excluding intentional or reckless misconduct. The curr_chunk addresses the ability of national governing bodies to develop policies to prevent individuals accused of sexual misconduct from interacting with minors or amateur athletes until the allegation is resolved. The curr_chunk states that the text was amended by replacing "may" with "shall" in certain instances. It was passed by the House of Representatives on May 25, 2017.
